youtubeVideos.title: Lesson 1 - Introduction to Excel
youtubeVideos.description: Overview of the Excel window, workbook vs worksheet, rows, columns, and navigation.

videoScript: Welcome to Lesson 1: Introduction to Excel. In this video you will learn how the Excel window is organised and how to move confidently inside a workbook like someone who uses Excel every day in the office.
blogArticle: In most real jobs Excel is the default tool for lists, reports and small calculations. Before you can build dashboards or automate anything you must be comfortable with the Excel environment. In this lesson you will see the ribbon, tabs, formula bar, status bar and sheet tabs. You will learn the difference between a workbook and a worksheet and how rows, columns and cells fit together. You will also practice opening, saving and closing workbooks so that nothing important is lost.
practiceProblems: Open Excel and identify the title bar, ribbon, formula bar and status bar. Say each name out loud once.
Create a new workbook, rename Sheet1 to Data_2025 and save the file on your desktop with the name Lesson1-Intro.xlsx.
Use the keyboard arrows and Page Up/Page Down keys to move around the sheet and notice how the active cell address changes.
homework: Create a new workbook with 3 worksheets named Sales, HR and Notes. Save it as Lesson1-Homework.xlsx.
On the Sales sheet type a small 3x3 sample table with any numbers just to practice typing and moving cells.
Close Excel and reopen your file to confirm that the sheet names and sample data are still correct.

quiz.question: What is the correct name for a single Excel file that can contain multiple worksheets?
quiz.explanation: One Excel file is called a workbook. Inside one workbook you can have many worksheets.

quiz.question: Which part of the Excel window shows the contents or formula of the currently selected cell?
quiz.explanation: The formula bar shows what is inside the active cell, whether it is a value, text or formula.

quiz.question: Which of the following best describes a worksheet?
options: One tab or grid inside a workbook
A backup copy of your data
quiz.explanation: A worksheet is a single tab or grid within a workbook. One workbook can have many worksheets.

quiz.question: Rows in Excel are identified by:
options: Letters such as A, B, C
quiz.explanation: Rows are numbered (1, 2, 3, …) while columns are labelled with letters (A, B, C, …).

quiz.question: Columns in Excel are identified by:
options: Letters such as A, B, C
quiz.explanation: Columns are labelled with letters. The combination of column and row gives a cell address like B3.

quiz.question: The cell at the intersection of column B and row 5 is written as:
quiz.explanation: Excel cell addresses are written as ColumnLetterRowNumber, so column B and row 5 is B5.

quiz.question: Which action is the safest way to close Excel without losing your recent changes?
quiz.explanation: You should always save your workbook before closing Excel to avoid losing changes.

quiz.question: Which keyboard keys are most commonly used to move the active cell up, down, left and right?
quiz.explanation: The arrow keys move the active cell around the grid one step at a time.

quiz.question: If you want to quickly jump to the very last used cell in a column, which key combination is often used?
quiz.explanation: Ctrl + Arrow (such as Ctrl + Down Arrow) jumps to the last used cell in that direction.

quiz.question: Why is it important to understand the basic layout of Excel (ribbon, grid, sheet tabs) before learning formulas?
options: Because formulas are not used in jobs
Because layout knowledge helps you navigate quickly and avoids frustration later
Because Excel will not work otherwise
quiz.explanation: Comfort with the Excel layout reduces friction so you can focus on solving problems instead of fighting the interface.

assignments.title: Identify Key Parts of the Excel Window
assignments.description: Open Excel and explore all major parts of the interface.
assignments.example:
Task: List the names of at least five UI elements (for example ribbon, formula bar, status bar).
Expected Behaviour: You can point to each part on the screen when someone says the name.
assignments.hiddenAnswer: Typical list: Title bar, Ribbon, Quick Access Toolbar, Formula Bar, Name Box, Worksheet Area (grid), Status Bar, Sheet Tabs.

assignments.title: Create a 3-Sheet Workbook
assignments.description: Practice adding and renaming sheets inside a single workbook.
assignments.example:
Task: Make a workbook with sheets named Sales_2025, HR_2025 and Notes.
Expected Behaviour: All three sheet names appear at the bottom and the file is saved as Intro-3Sheets.xlsx.
assignments.hiddenAnswer: Use the plus icon to insert new sheets, double-click the sheet tab to rename, then press Ctrl+S and choose the filename Intro-3Sheets.xlsx.

assignments.title: Navigate Using Only Keyboard
assignments.description: Move around a worksheet using the keyboard instead of the mouse.
assignments.example:
Task: Starting from A1, reach cell H25 using only arrow keys, Page Up/Down and Ctrl+Arrow.
Expected Behaviour: You can move to far cells without using the mouse.
assignments.hiddenAnswer: Use arrow keys for small moves, Page Down/Up for bigger jumps, and Ctrl+Arrow to jump to edges of data blocks.

assignments.title: Save and Reopen Safely
assignments.description: Ensure you never lose work while practicing Excel.
assignments.example:
Task: Create any small table, save the workbook, close Excel and reopen the file.
Expected Behaviour: The table should look exactly the same after reopening.
assignments.hiddenAnswer: Click File → Save or press Ctrl+S; note the folder and name. After closing, reopen Excel and use Recent or browse to the file location.

assignments.title: Create a Simple Contact List
assignments.description: Practice basic typing in the grid structure.
assignments.example:
Task: Create a sheet with columns Name, Phone and City with at least 5 rows.
Expected Behaviour: Data is in a neat rectangular block with headers in the first row.
assignments.hiddenAnswer: Type headers in row 1, start data in row 2, keep each piece of information in its own column and do not leave blank rows inside the table.

assignments.title: Explain Workbook vs Worksheet in Your Own Words
assignments.description: Check your conceptual understanding with a short explanation.
assignments.example:
Task: Write a two-line explanation in a cell or notebook.
Expected Behaviour: You can explain to a non-technical friend without mentioning theory words.
assignments.hiddenAnswer: Example answer: 'A workbook is an Excel file. Inside it you can have many worksheets, like pages in a register. Each worksheet is a grid where you actually type your data.'

assignments.title: Use Zoom to View More or Less of the Sheet
assignments.description: Learn how zooming affects your view of the grid.
assignments.example:
Task: Change zoom to 70% and then to 120% on a sample sheet.
Expected Behaviour: At low zoom you see more cells; at high zoom text is larger.
assignments.hiddenAnswer: Use the zoom slider in the status bar or View → Zoom. Zoom does not change data, only how big or small it appears on your screen.

assignments.title: Check the Active Cell Address
assignments.description: Become comfortable reading cell addresses from the Name Box.
assignments.example:
Task: Click in random places on the grid and read the active cell address aloud.
Expected Behaviour: You can confidently say addresses like C7, H12, A1.
assignments.hiddenAnswer: The Name Box to the left of the formula bar always shows the address of the active cell.

assignments.title: Jump Between Worksheets
assignments.description: Practice switching between multiple sheets quickly.
assignments.example:
Task: Create three sheets and switch between them using mouse and keyboard.
Expected Behaviour: You can show data on different sheets without getting lost.
assignments.hiddenAnswer: Click the sheet tabs with the mouse or use Ctrl+PgUp / Ctrl+PgDn to move between sheets using the keyboard.

assignments.title: Write a Mini Reflection
assignments.description: Think about where Excel might be used in your life or local businesses.
assignments.example:
Task: In a Notes sheet, list three places where you think Excel is used (for example coaching centre fees, small shop stock list).
Expected Behaviour: You can see Excel as a tool for real situations, not just an abstract app.
assignments.hiddenAnswer: Any real-life examples are valid as long as they involve lists or small calculations, such as class attendance, expense tracking or shop inventory.
